      • formatAddress

        public static java.lang.String formatAddress(short[] addressParts)
        Generate a string representing just the address part without the [], prefix or portrange. This accounts for the case of an IPv4-form address being represented in IPv6 format.
        Parameters:
        addressParts -
        Returns:

      • newIPv6Instance

        public static IPv6Address newIPv6Instance(java.lang.String ipv6AddressString)
                                   throws java.text.ParseException
        Specs not clear on format of a "prefix". It could be either "["
        [ "/" ] "]" [ ":" portrange ] or "["
        "]" [ "/" ] [ ":" portrange ] but we cannot tell which the specs are saying. To avoid problems in the future it seems safest to implement both of these formats.
        Parameters:
        ipv6AddressString -
        Returns:
        Throws:
        java.text.ParseException

      • isIPv6Address

        public static boolean isIPv6Address(java.lang.String ipv4AddressString)
        Guess whether or not the given string is intended to be an IPv6 address. Because there may be all kinds of errors in the representation, the only way to know that it is a legal IPv6 address is to fully parse it, and if the parse fails then we only know that is is not a legal IPv6 address (it might be a legal IPv4 or other address). We could just have the IPAddress.newInstance method call the full parser and do some quick checks there. The disadvantage of that is that we would need to set up a try/catch (expensive) and in many cases there would be unneeded method calls involved. So we take a guess here.
        Parameters:
        ipv4AddressString -
        Returns:

      • stringValue

        public java.lang.String stringValue()
        The specifications are ambiguous on how to handle /prefix in IPv6. There are two possibilities and the documents are silent on how to handle it, and no examples are readily apparent on the internet. The two possible representations are: [
        /prefix] and [
        ]/prefix The prefix is optional as is the ":<portrange>" that can follow it. We have chosen to use the first representation because the prefix seems to be part of the address itself, which is supposed to be inside the brackets.
        Specified by:
        stringValue in interface SemanticString
        Specified by:
        stringValue in class IPAddress
        Returns:
        the semantically significant String representation of the object implementing this interface.
